topic.title: Why I No Longer Vote
topic.body:
http://misc-stuff.terraaeon.com/articles/no-vote.html

This post was pulled from Hacker News, so I thought it would probably be appropriate to post it on ZeroNet.

Why I No Longer Vote
5-6-20

Reading Vane Vander's article Vow has jolted me out of the writer's block that I have been experiencing for the past two months. Actually, it is more like a life-long writer's block that occasionally lifts long enough to allow me to write something that could perhaps enlighten someone. Enlightening people is such a difficult task, because so few bother to read or think for themselves. I should probably give up my attempts altogether and spend my time writing pure fiction. But again, I have writer's block. Perhaps, if I spent more time reading, my writer's block might lift long enough to develop some good ideas, but my latest life adventure--creating websites--has been interfering with my reading. I think that is probably a good thing--doing, rather than just reading about other people doing. For the moment, I find that I really enjoy creating websites, even though it keeps me from reading and writing about other things.

Vane's perceptive and articulate article is basically about not letting yourself fall into the trap of "groupthink" in order to feel like you have a place in the universe, i.e. with other people. Unfortunately for me, it has taken me decades longer in my life to realize the truthfulness of her words than it has taken her in her life come up with them. I now see that when we align ourselves with a cause, we often succumb to the temptation to hand off our thinking and decision making authority to a "team captain", who we follow blindly. Even when some of his thoughts and decisions are ridiculous, we often have great difficulty taking back our autonomy.

Sometime less than twenty years ago, I recognized that voting and paying attention to politics for any reason other than its entertainment value is a waste of my time. In theory, voting is an expression of youthful hope in the system that the founding fathers of republicanism envisioned, and it should be applauded. In reality, it is no more beneficial to society than drawing straws to see which lieing politician will receive the next opportunity to abuse his or her power over us. Perhaps it is unfair of me to characterize all politicians as liars, but there does seem to be something about the psyches of people who run for public office that validates the stereotype. Don't get me wrong, I am by no means an anarchist or monarchist. I just don't feel that my country has ever lived up to its ideals sufficiently to be anywhere close to counteracting the destructiveness of human nature. Maybe that is just me seeing the glass as half empty, instead of half full.

We are left with politicians who lie to us to get power. After we vote for them, they do whatever they want. And, it seems that no matter their party, they all want the same things with power. For example, Bill Clinton, a democrat, supposedly a man for the little people, backer of labor unions, head of "the most ethical administration ever", signed NAFTA into law. NAFTA has been throwing jobs out of the US for decades now--taking jobs from exactly those who Clinton claimed to be protecting. I doubt those jobs will return to the US any time soon, even with the glaring problems associated with having everything made in China that Covid-19 has recently exposed--yet again. I could give other examples, but why? If you don't see the truth in what I have said so far, no amount of evidence will sway you.

One of the things I have been learning as I age is pointed out by Vane in her article. I have been learning not to waste my time fruitlessly supporting groups that have goals for society. Whether they are religious or political. My guess is that individuals do not change because society changes. Society changes because individuals change. But, I am not a psychologist, so that is just a guess. There could be more of a feedback mechanism there than I can perceive. One thing I am fairly certain of is that, if there is a feedback mechanism, it is detrimental to society as often as it is beneficial.

Something else I now understand is that freedom comes not from society but from within the mind of the individual. Freedom is an individual thing, not a societal thing. We become free as we learn to think freely and live our lives in ways consistent with free thought. I suspect this is a concept that is ineffable. So, there is no point in talking about it further, although I won't promise not to do so in some future article, provided my writer's block allows it.

UPDATE: This article was pulled from Hacker News less than half an hour after I submitted it, but not before it had received nearly a thousand page views. I've never had an article pulled from Hacker News before. Perhaps, we have even less free speech in the US than I thought. This is why everyone should have his own website.

topic.title: How do you do content discovery?
topic.body:
Discovering interesting content doesn't seem to be easy, especially on zeronet, which zites are not reachable from major search engine.

There are several search engine for zeronet out there. They works at a certain degree. For example they can search the site by title of some additional meta data, however, full-text search on zeronet sounds a tough work.

Even in the clearnet, active searching is not the only way we discover interesting content. We subscribe to some meta index, like hackersnews and blogs.

How do you do content discovery? on the clearnet and on zeronet. Look forward to hear from the peers.

topic.title: (re-post) UN Proposal to Ban Fictional Works as "Child Pornography"
topic.body:
source: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB/1550688635

# **UN Proposal to Ban Fictional Works as "Child Pornography"**

The United Nations is asking for feedback on a [new set of proposals](https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/DraftGuidelinesOPs.aspx) for the international community to rally against child prostitution, the sale of children, and child pornography.

## Sounds great, right?

But a close look at their definition of child pornography reveals that this extends a little bit beyond that. [Drawings, cartoons, written stories, sculptures, and other forms of fictional works](https://www.oneangrygamer.net/2019/02/u-n-proposes-initiativ…ban-loli-shota-and-underage-drawings-and-cartoons/77229/amp/) are also tucked in under the guise of "child pornography".

A progressive new CSA (child sexual abuse) prevention organization, Prostasia Foundation, recently did [an excellent writeup](https://prostasia.org/blog/experts-to-united-nations-hentai-ban-would-be-a-mistake/) on this UN proposal.

## **This ban may be counterproductive at preventing CSA**

There is no evidence that banning fictitious works has this effect. [Some experts](http://www.sexologytoday.org/2017/02/canada-and-australia-now-have-both.html) do [believe](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/01/can-child-dolls-keep-pedophiles-from-offending/423324/) bans, such as what the UN guidelines as written seek to ban, could actually lead to a rise in CSA.

With zero evidence that banning these things helps children, and with experts fearing that bans like this could put children in jeopardy, it is absolutely premature to implement such a ban until the necessary research has been conducted.

there is no evidence that banning fictitious works has any impact on reducing CSA (child sexual abuse). [some](http://www.sexologytoday.org/2017/02/canada-and-australia-now-have-both.html) [experts](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/01/can-child-dolls-keep-pedophiles-from-offending/423324/) believe that bans on the types of things these UN guidelines seek to ban will actually lead to a rise in CSA.

## **This ban is a gross violation of freedom of speech and expression**

This will have chilling effects.

Most anime, which frequently features high school aged characters, will fall under fire for having "underage" characters depicted. Novels, comics, fanfiction, art, fanart, sculptures, and other creative works featuring characters that "appear underage" (aka under 18) will similarly be harmed by the implementation of these international guidelines.

Websites operating in countries that follow these UN guidelines may find themselves reluctant to support anime or artist communities, since their duty to police content will become even more strict. We have seen the chilling effects on speech that puritan policies such as this have (see: Reddit's [harsh subreddit bans](https://piunikaweb.com/2019/02/12/reddit-facing-massive-public-outcry-after-alleged-loli-crackdown/), Steam's [removal of adult games featuring high school aged girls](https://nichegamer.com/2018/12/06/all-ages-modified-vn-hello-good-bye-banned-on-steam/)).

## **We need to tell the UN that fictional children are not children**

Although the UN's intentions are surely noble, equating artwork to child pornography is a farce which undermines the very concept of harm that CP creation and dissemination has on children, and a slap in the face to survivors of childhood sexual abuse, whose very real depictions of abuse and trauma continue to circulate throughout the internet.

Anyone who would like to join me in presenting opposition to parts of the UN's proposal can do so. They are accepting comments by email. **Comments must be submitted by 31 March 2019.**

* You can [email the UN](crc@ohchr.org) directly, following their [guidelines on submissions](https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/DraftGuidelinesOPs.aspx).
* Prostasia has created a [form to submit a pre-written email](https://prostasia.org/campaign/art-not-csem/) signed in your name.

**If you are an active member in anime or artist communities, please help spread the word about this issue. Together, we can convey to the UN and the international community why this new attack on free speech will not be tolerated.**

[ZeroMedium post](/ZeroMedium.bit/?/1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB/un-proposal-to-ban-fictional-works-as-child-pornography)

Doubtful, besides the whole point of a distributed internet is to make censorship impossible. I don't personally agree with much of the content others provide, but I do believe that people have a right to say and post what they want to, and as a relay node I believe we have a duty to not filter the information flow. If you choose to provide content that is illegal where you live, and that content is discovered in your possession then you will have to face the consequences for that decision.

So, assume the worst, and encrypt everything. You can run a Whonix VM with whole disk encryption and then encrypt the disk the VM is on with VeraCrypt. PGP with a long random key has never been broken by any agency as far as I know.

Disagreeing with the law is pointless, but the censorship issue brings me around to what I consider to be a valid point. Focus on catching the people producing illegal content and stop trying to filter and moderate the data transfers of the entire population en masse.
